captions.text:
MATT FARAH: If you've ever
watched a video on Drive, then
you know what this is.

It's the Cadillac CTS-V. It has
larger grill openings to

feed the supercharged engine
and Brembo brakes.

It has a G-Meter, which is a
cool feature even on a wagon.

And since 2009, it has been the
go-to example for every

American YouTube commenter
responding to any comment

regarding any vehicle wearing
a badge that says either AMG

or M. Some of them, amazingly,
have a point, since it's

faster and cheaper than
almost any other super
sedan money can buy.

Others argue that it still
suffers from issues which

plague all GM vehicles, that,
despite the performance, it's

simply not as satisfying to
drive, or as solidly built, as
something from Germany.

But that's not why we are
talking about it.

We're here today because the
Cadillac CTS-V makes an
amazing platform for tuning.

And of all the companies that
modify these vehicles, D3 is
one of the best.

In an effort to make the CTS-V
more interesting to people

like me, D3 has done something
that I wholeheartedly approve
of, added a [BLEEP]
load of horsepower.
Let's see how that feels.
[LAUGHS]
Traction may be an issue here.
Let's go to manual mode.

All right, now, first things
first, this is
an automatic car.

And that's because the customer
uses it as a daily
driver around LA.

So I don't entirely
disagree with his
choice of the automatic.

However, the automatic does do
one thing, and that is over

exaggerate that the LS engine is
sort of lazy, for lack of a
better word.

In automatic mode, it doesn't
really want to rev. It keeps

everything below 2000 RPM,
unless you really mat it.

So, I would go with
a stick because
that's just how I roll.
But such is life.

We've got paddles, and
we'll make it work.
Sounds brilliant, doesn't it?

Now this car makes approximately
750 horsepower

at the crank, 650 horsepower at
the wheels, and 640 pounds

of torque at the wheels, which
is a ton of power to move
around the car.
Sounds incredible--

long tube headers, X-pipe, big
Corsa exhaust, three inches
all the way back.

MATT HARBER: The LSA engine
really likes to take anything
that you throw at it.

The engine itself also takes a
lot of internal work as well,

if you want it to go above
and beyond on anything.
So the platform is great.

It's easy for us to engineer, to
basically kind of dream up

horsepower numbers and go
chase after them without

having to rip apart and,
basically, make it a totally
different car.

MATT FARAH: This is what
they call their
Stage 4 Power Upgrade.

And what you get for that, for
such a high number, is
actually not all that much.
It helps it breathe better.

You get an intake,
a throttle body.

It gets more fuel in there,
a bigger fuel
pump, bigger injectors.

And, they get more boost
out of the blower.

They have a smaller pulley on
there to make more boost.

But in order to reduce the
strains on the blower, they've

added a spacer, which gives the
blower more displacement.

That way you can add more boost
to it without worrying

about heat and that kind of
stuff or over revving the
supercharger.
And it works pretty good.

The one thing you really want
to worry about when you're

modifying a car with a Roots
blower on it is heat soak.

A Corvette ZR1, a lot of these
cars, will get one, two,
really good dyno pulls.

And then the blower gets heat
soaked, and you start losing
power really fast.

Now in order to fight that,
D3 has added a massive
intercooler.
It's 5 and 1/2 inches thick.

MATT HARBER: We designed an
intercooler that holds about

1.6 gallons of fluid and also
added a 20-gallon per minute

pump to keep that fluid cycling
through as quick as

possible without any lag time to
address the heating issues

that come with running
a supercharged car.

Our intercooler is the biggest
possible intercooler that we
can fit in that car.
It basically--

we left maybe an eighth of an
inch on each side, and the
bumper fits back on to stock.

So it still has that stock look,
but we maximized the

space underneath there
and ate every little
square inch of it up.

MATT FARAH: Now D3 offers
packages, like the Stage 4

Power Upgrade, but they also
want to customize to the

owner's taste for what they
want to do with the car.

This owner daily drives the
car, but he also races it

competitively in the Cadillac
Challenge Series, which is a
time attack series.

So, in order to back up all
that power and keep things

under control, they upgraded
the brakes.

There's a two-piece Brembo
floating caliper now up front.

And they've upgraded the discs
as well to cross-drilled,
vented, two-piece discs.

They're the same size as stock,
but they work better

with a better fluid compound,
better pad compound, and the
stainless steel brake lines.

And actually, let's
see how those feel
going down into second.
They're very good, actually.
I'm kind of impressed by that.

Oh man, does that
sound amazing.
Now, the suspension--

the magnetic ride control that
comes with this car is very
good on the street.

It's got the dual mode, comfort,
and sport, and it's
pretty good for the track.

But if you're actually going for
lap times, pushing the car

to its limit, and sometimes even
beyond its limit, it's

just not enough, which is why
they installed the KW Variant
3 coil-over set up.

Now we come to our first
problem, ride height.

You see, it's a fine line
between what looks cool at a

show, works on the track,
and is actually
practical for the street.

Now I went through this with my
own Corvette, and I, quite

frankly, made it too low, and
it rubbed everywhere.

And that's what's
happening here.

You see, there's only about
three inches of ground
clearance here.

So instead of pulling off into
the dirt, like a normal person

would do safely, I literally
cannot clear this little

three-inch curb without
scraping the entire
undercarriage of the car.

I understand if it was an
exclusively track car, but

honestly, this suspension needs
to be raised up at least

an inch if you want to drive
it on the street.

You've got a lot
of horsepower.

One of the things you
really have to worry
about is grip, of course.

And on that front, they
have taken steps
to improve the grip.

My Corvette, by example, makes
420 wheel horsepower, but has

12-inch rear tires on it,
305s to be exact.

This car has 50% more horsepower
than that, but it

only has 9 and 1/2-inch
rear tires.

So managing that throttle coming
out of a corner is
extremely important here.

On the other hand, they've
switched to a square stance.

The CTS-V comes with 255s up
front from the factory, but

now they're running
295s all around.

And what that does is, by
getting more meat upfront, it

dials out a bunch of the factory
understeer that comes
with this car.

This is, honestly, too much
car for this road.

MATT FARAH: This thing will run
an 11-second quarter mile
all day, low 11s.

In fact, it could even run in
the high 10s with the right

set of tires on it and
a good driver, if you
could launch it properly.
But it also handles.

I mean, it's a 4,200,
4,300 pound car.

And with this suspension setup,
I'm feeling pretty

confident going through these
corners right now.

Although the body work on the
CTS-V is basically stock,

there are a couple of parts that
have been changed, such

as this carbon fiber
wing blade here.

Now, while I was at the shop
this morning, I noticed some

of their body work was
excellently done, especially
the wide body kit.

I do have to question this piece
because it's basically

just a double-sided tape
piece of carbon.

And it's coming up here,
and see that?

That's the tape coming
unstuck.

And so I might question the more
expensive body work if
it's like this.

The question I want to
leave you with--
is this car a sleeper?
Can it be a sleeper?

I mean, yes, it is based on a
556-horsepower production car.

And anyone who knows and sees
that chrome grill coming and

the V badge is going to know
what's under there.

But on the other hand, at first
glance, it looks like a

car you can rent from
Hertz for $65 a day.

And certainly no one's going
to expect that under a

stock-looking CTS-V is 750
horsepower worth of nut sack.
So can it be a sleeper?

Can you call this
car a sleeper?
I think you can.

I think if you can call a CTS-V
wagon a sleeper, you can

call a fully-worked CTS-V
sedan a sleeper.
I think that's OK.

But I want to know
what you think.

Is it a sleeper, or is
it just too fast and
too new to be a sleeper?

So let me know, leave a
comment on that guy.

On paper, the car does
everything as advertised.
It's way faster than stock.

It stops way shorter, and it
corners way better than when
it was stock.

But the feel of driving it
somehow just isn't as fun as I
wanted it to be.

It could be the annoyingly low
suspension or the fact that I

got little weird noises that I
wasn't expecting and that you

wouldn't really want from the
refinement of a Cadillac.

It could be the ill-fitting
carbon fiber wing.

But really, it's the automatic
transmission.

That transmission just sucks the
life right out of this car

and makes it so much less fun
than if it were stick or even

a proper dual-clutch
transmission.

It doesn't match the
set up, and that's
what I'm talking about.

If you're going to put all this
money into a car, all

this performance into a car, why
ruin it with an automatic?

So guys, your car's awesome
but please, next
time get me a stick.
Until then, I'm Matt Farah.

And you're been watching
Tuned, right here
on the Drive Network.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text:
Well a sleeper refers to the fact that it doesn't draw attention to itself 
and it doesn't suggest the HP under the hood. I'd say a stock CTS-V, 
especially a V wagon, is an excellent example of a sleeper. This one in the 
video may be too loud to be a sleeper, but a stock one fits the definition. 
 Example: At a gas station recently I had my CTS-V wagon (with 730 HP) at 
one pump, and a guy with a bright red Charger SRT8 was at the next one 
over. People were flocking to his car and admiring the engine etc.

Meanwhile nobody was even looking at my car. Not even a glance. And it 
would have completely destroyed that Charger in a race. THAT is what I call 
a sleeper. Nobody knows what it is, or expects the beatdown that is coming.

There are better examples of sleepers, like monster miatas or any 
LS-swapped anything, but as stock cars go the CTS-V is one of the sleepiest.

comments.text:
+pikl2r Mile High V is correct to a point, but failed to explain "how does 
it effect the power of the car?"...

Heat soak to a supercharger causes the incoming air to heat up. COLD air is 
preferred because it is more dense, thus the air-fuel mixture is more dense 
and contains more power (increased O2 + increased hydrocarbons) put cubic 
unit. Hot air, on the other hand, is less dense due to expansion, thanks to 
the excitability of air molecules when heated (think hot-air balloon). This 
is why engines have more horsepower in cold weather (e.g. winter) than in 
hot weather (e.g. Arizona 110 degree summer).
comments.author: R Ruddock

comments.text:
+Mile High V
Well thanks very much for the answer there sir!! :)
comments.author: pikl2r

comments.text:
The supercharger gets hot while under boost, in turn it heats up the 
intercooler and fluid.  It takes time for the front mount intercooler (heat 
exchanger) to decrease these temps.  Larger front mount intercooler (HX) 
helps battle this problem, but not nearly as quick as it takes to heat it 
up.  Heatons (er, I mean Eatons) on cars such as the V are notorious for 
this, especially when over spun like most modders do.

I have to run ice through my reservoir box before and after each run at the 
drag strip if I want to make an impressive pass.  But, I'm also very much 
overspinning my blower.  One solution would be a much larger blower...which 
isn't a realistic option on the V, at least not yet.

comments.text:
+Vernon Price & contagious6969
Automatics SHIFT faster! Constantly in gear. Just springs and check valves 
to redirect the trans fluid to get to the next gear.
But...that viscous fluid is heavy. The centrifugal forces of the torque 
converter spinning that fluid in order to create the pressure required to 
open/close the check valves are in effect which creates parasitic drag 
requiring MORE horsepower to carry that weight. It also creates heat. A 
known proven power killer. That 'ease of use' comes with a penalty
Stick shifts require a release of the clutch, a physical gear change from 
one gear, past neutral, into the next gear, followed by the clutch being 
re-engaged.
An auto has no interruption of the power being put to the wheels, as is so 
with a stick.
Even 'No-lift' power shifting can't get around that fact.
That being said, the parasitic drag of a stick shift is a fraction of the 
automatic.
Therefore, MORE power is available to the wheels. Especially apparent when 
comparing identical vehicles, save for the difference in transmissions.
Apples to apples, y'kow?
Now, IF that is understood, the 'driving experience', & the end use of one 
over the other is a personal choice. What do YOU want?
Jump in with your triple grande 1/2 fat vanilla latte in one hand, Ipod/pad 
in the other, drop it into drive, an crank up the Montavani, & numbly 
commute while being ensconced & totally devoid of any input from the 
vehicle while it does it's thing, AUTOMATICALLY? Yawwwwwwwn!
Or...would you rather be PART of the driving experience? To have actual 
physical input into the how the vehicle reacts & behaves as according to 
YOU?
Besides, a driver with a stick shift is not necessarily a better driver, 
but more aware. Especially apparent when negotiating hills, corners, & 
stop-n-go traffic. Driving a stick requires that the operator makes CHOICES 
as dictated by the physical surroundings. Driving with an auto in the same 
situation? Mash it & go! (Be careful though. Don't wanna spill that $5.00 
latte!) There is NO time to be sucking back a cuppa, or diddling on a 
personal communication device.
I'll even go as far as saying that new drivers should be required to drive 
for the first 2 years behind the wheel of a stick. (As did I.) I'll 
garauntee that at the end of that time, they WILL be a better driver than 
someone whom has driven an auto, exclusively!
I'm not saying one is better than the other. They both have their place in 
the automotive world. I AM saying that daily automatic drivers tend to be 
prone to being distracted, & lazy in their driving habits. (There's 'good' 
driving habits, & 'bad' driving habits.)
But...whatdya want to be? Just another droid cruising along mindlessly 
oblivious?
Or a 'driver'? Someone actually aware of the vehicle, how it's performing 
according to their own input & the surroundings they are in?
Without a phone in one hand, and coffee stains down the front of the Armani 
silk shirt! (So that's what a tie is for!)
Hey, you might even get to work with a smile on your face! How could the 
rest of the day go bad after a morning commute behind a stick?
I'd pick a stick over an auto anyday! Even with their inherent shortcomings!
 I like that positive control. Doesn't matter if it's a clapped out '50's 
Chevy pick-up with an inline six & a 3-on-the-tree, a '60's Muscle car 
with the clutch pressure requirements equal to a semi's, or a CTS-V with 
the not so common stick.
Real 'DRIVER'S' drive sticks!

comments.text:
+contagious6969 Why would me posting a video of a CTS-V affect anything at 
all in this discussion? Do you have an answer for that question? We're 
talking about facts, things like actual weight, drivetrain loss and basic 
math.

Trap speeds make all the difference because they show you which car is 
actually faster. If the auto does the 1/4 mile at 116 mph and the manual 
does it at 118 MPH, that means the manual is the faster car. There's 
nothing complicated about it.

If the auto "deals with it better" then how is the manual getting higher 
trap speeds? I'm guessing you don't have an answer for that. If my manual 
can cover the same distance as your auto and end up going 2 mph faster,

getting, or something?

Obviously you have never used no lift shift on the TR6060 in the CTS-V.
